contentrichtext.text: '''İske Qazan''' (literally: ''Old [[Kazan]]''; [[Cyrillic]]: Иске Казан), was a [[Volga Bulgaria|Bolghar]]-[[Volga Tatars|Tatar]] city in the 13-16th centuries, situated on the banks of the [[Kazanka River|Qazansu river]] in the ''[[Qazan artı]]'' or ''Zakazanye'' region, in what is today the [[Russia|Russian Federation]] [[Republics of Russia|republic]] of [[Tatarstan]] . In 18th century Tatar literature, İske Qazan was said to have been founded by the brothers ''Altınbäk and ''Ğälimbäk during [[Mongol invasion of Volga Bulgaria]]. In the 13-14th centuries the city was one of the political and economic centres of ''Qazan artı''. After raids by Russian armies in 1376 and 1399, the city's importance declined. In 1535, the exiled king [[Cangali khan|Canğäli khan]] lived in the city, where he probably died. In 1552 İske Qazan was ruined by Russian troops. Today the ''Urıs Urmatı'' and ''Qamay'' ruins are the ruins of İske Qazan. ==References== *{{TES|Иске Казан}} {{coord missing|Russia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Iske Qazan}} [[Category:Khanate of Kazan]] [[Category:Defunct towns in Russia]] [[Category:Archaeological sites in Tatarstan]] [[Category:Former populated places in Russia]] {{russia-hist-stub}}
